feed.title: Combined summary - CoinShuffle: decentralized CoinJoin without trusted third parties

entry.title: Combined summary - CoinShuffle: decentralized CoinJoin without trusted third parties
entry.summary: A group of German researchers has proposed a decentralized protocol for CoinJoin, called CoinShuffle, which allows for mixing coins among users to improve anonymity. The protocol is designed to implement CoinJoin without trusted third parties and provides a way to create a CoinJoin transaction with multiple input addresses and multiple fresh output addresses.However, the difficulty with CoinJoin is to let participants announce their fresh output addresses without breaking anonymity. CoinShuffle addresses this problem by having no third party in a run of the protocol and providing unlinkability of input and output addresses, security against thefts, robustness against denial-of-service attacks, only public-key encryption and signatures, efficiency, and compatibility with the current Bitcoin system. A proof-of-concept implementation is available on the project page, but it is only a demonstration of feasibility and not well-written. Plans are underway for a full, open-source implementation of the protocol. The discussion also revolves around the issues of ensuring validity at a certain level and how it can constrain the use cases of protocol implementations. One concern raised is that lite clients cannot perform a check on inputs, making the protocol vulnerable to DoS attacks. An alternative solution is to have participants submit the merkle proof for the input, but this requires inputs to have at least one confirmation.Additionally, Tim Ruffing raises concerns about the decentralization and security of CoinShuffle, questioning how users can securely communicate with each other and prevent Sybil attacks, where one attacker poses as multiple users. There are several solutions proposed, including using direct connections to a randomly elected leader, overlay networks like distributed hash tables or Bitmessage, dividing users into individual groups, and using the hash of all users' public keys in the pool to determine the assignment. Although there is no perfect solution, several proposals work well enough if implemented correctly.Overall, CoinShuffle has several features that make it an attractive solution for those looking to improve anonymity in Bitcoin without requiring changes to the Bitcoin protocol. The researchers plan to create an open-source implementation of the protocol and would like to build on top of an existing widespread client. The conversation also covers the use of lightweight clients in a protocol, with alternative solutions such as getUTXO or verifying the validity of the transaction that created the input designated for mixing must be considered to ensure the security of the protocol.Finally, the conversation touches on the issue of de-anonymization in protocols. Sergio Lerner suggested that the second party in a protocol can de-anonymize the first party, but Tim disagreed, stating that the second party doesn't know how the third, fourth, fifth, etc., parties shuffled the outputs as it doesn't have their decryption keys.
